i  in general administration except as otherwise provided herein the city manager will administer implement and enforce the provisions of this chapter the city manager may delegate any powers or duties to other city personnel  31102 abbreviations the following abbreviations when used in this chapter have the meanings indicated below awwa stands for the american water works association bmp stands for best management practice cod stands for chemical oxygen demand cbod stands for carbonaceous biochemical oxygen demand cfr stands for the federal regulations epa stands for the u s environmental protection agency gpd stands for gallons per day mgl stands for milligrams per liter mgd stands for million 1000000 gallons per day naics stands for north american industrial classification system npdes stands for the national pollutant discharge elimination system osha stands for the occupational safety and health administration potw stands for publicly owned treatment works ppm stands for parts per million 1000000 rcra stands for the resource conservation and recovery act siu stands for significant industrial user trc stands for total residual chlorine tss stands for total suspended solids usc stands for united states  31102   102411 definitions the following words and phrases when used in this chapter have the meanings indicated below abutting means adjacent or contiguous to or located immediately across from any road street rightofway or easement act or the act means the federal water pollution control act also known as the clean water act as amended 33 usc  1251 et seq alternative water system connection fee means any alternative fee calculated by an applicant and approved by the city commission pursuant to this article alternative water system connection fee study means a study prepared by an applicant or owner and submitted to the city pursuant to this article alternative sewer system connection fee means any alternative fee calculated by an applicant and approved by the city commission pursuant to this article alternative sewer system connection fee study means a study prepared by an applicant or owner and submitted to the city pursuant this article applicant means the person who individually or as the authorized representative of an organization or corporation signs an application for utility service requesting water or sewer service at a specific location for a specific use authorized representative of the user means 1 if the user is a corporation a the president secretary treasurer or a vicepresident of the corporation in charge of a principal business function or any other person who performs similar policy or decisionmaking functions for the corporation  or b the manager of one 1 or more manufacturing production or operation facilities provided the manager is authorized to make management decisions that govern the operation of the regulated facility including having the explicit or implicit duty of making major capital investment recommendations and initiate compliance with environmental laws and regulations  can ensure that the necessary systems are established or actions taken to gather complete and accurate information for individual wastewater discharge permit requirements  and where the authority to sign documents has been assigned or delegated to the manager in accordance with corporate procedures 2 if the user is a partnership or sole proprietorship a general partner or proprietor respectively 3 if the user is a federal state or local governmental facility a director or highest official appointed or designated to oversee the operation and performance of the activities of the government facility or their designee 4 the individuals described in paragraphs 1 3 above may designate a duly authorized representative if a the authorization is in writing  b the authorization specifies the individual or position responsible for the overall operation of the facility from which the discharge originates or having overall responsibility for environmental matters for the company  and c the authorization is submitted to and received by the city backflow means a flow of water from the customers side of the meter into the city water system under conditions where the water pressure on the customers side of the meter exceeds the pressure in the city water system backflow preventer means a mechanical device installed in conjunction with a water meter to prevent a flow of water from the customers side of the meter into the city water system best management practices bmps means schedules of activities prohibitions of practices maintenance procedures and other management practices to implement the prohibitions listed in section 2678 bmps include treatment requirements operating procedures and practices to control plant site runoff spillage or leaks sludge or waste disposal or drainage from raw materials storage building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the sewer lateral or public sewer at the property line or other lawful place of disposal bypass means the intentional diversion of waste streams from any portion of a users treatment facility carbonaceous biochemical oxygen demand cbod means the amount of oxygen expressed in parts per million 1000000 necessary to satisfy the oxygen requirements of the carbonaceous fraction of a sample of wastewater incubated for five 5 days at twenty 20 degrees celsius 20 c and tested in accordance with standard methods categorical industrial user means an industrial user subject to a categorical pretreatment standard or categorical standard categorical pretreatment standard means any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the epa in accordance with b and c of the act 33 usc  1317 which apply to a specific category of users and which appear in 40 cfr subchapter n parts 405471 chemical oxygen demand cod means the amount of oxygen required to oxidize all compounds both organic and inorganic in water city means the city of st augustine as established by the charter laws of the city of st augustine city manager means the administrative head of the municipal government as established by the charter laws of the city of st augustine or designee city water system means the entire water utility system that services the needs of the customer and which includes a water source treatment facilities pumps transmission and distribution lines fire hydrants valves meters backflow preventers and all other related appurtenances city sewer system see publicly owned treatment works connection charges means specific development charges that must be satisfied in order to receive water or wastewater service connection charges include collection transmission and distribution fees  treatment plant fees  tapping fees  backflow preventer fees  hydrant fees  permit fees  asphalt and roadway repair fees  main extension fees  and inspection fees control authority means the city crossconnection means any physical arrangement whereby the city water system is connected directly or indirectly to any other water system sewer drain conduit pool storage reservoir plumbing fixture or other device which may contain contaminated water sewage or other waste or liquid of unknown or unsafe quality which may be capable of contaminating the city water system as the result of backflow bypass arrangements jumper connections removable sections swivel or changeable devices and other temporary or permanent devices or because of which backflow could occur are considered crossconnections customer means the person responsible for paying the water sewer or stormwater billed for service provided at a specific location daily maximum means the arithmetic average of all effluent samples for a pollutant collected during a calendar day daily maximum limit means the maximum allowable discharge limit of a pollutant during a calendar day where daily maximum limits are expressed in units of mass the daily discharge is the total mass discharged over the course of a day where daily maximum limits are expressed in terms of concentration the daily discharge is the arithmetic average of the pollutant concentration derived from all measurements taken during that day deposit means the amount of money placed with the city by each customer as security for payment of the water sewer or stormwater bill development means any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate discharge means the introduction of pollutants into the potw from any nondomestic source regulated under b c or d of the act easement means any strip of land created by a subdivider for public or private utilities drainage sanitation or other specified uses having limitations the title to which remains in the name of the property owner subject to the right of use designated in the reservation of the servitude effluent means the discharge flow of a treatment facility employees means the maximum number of owners partners workers other hired help or volunteers normally present at a commercial or industrial establishment during an eighthour shift existing source means any source of discharge that is not a new source extension means a water or sewer facility constructed to enable the provision of water or sewer service flammable means as defined by the city fire regulations flow means projected water andor wastewater use expressed in gallons per day gpd forcemain means a line which carries wastewater under pressure from a pump station grab sample means an individual discrete sample collected at a specific time a grab sample includes all sub samples or aliquots eg individual containers for specific analytes or analyte groups and sample fractions eg field sample duplicates or split samples collected at the same locations within a time not exceeding 15 minutes gravity sewer means a nonpressurized wastewater collection line that moves wastewater from one 1 location to another industrial pretreatment coordinator means city personnel designated by the city manager to operate and administer the citys industrial pretreatment program industrial user means a source of discharge influent means the flow arriving at a treatment plant for treatment instantaneous maximum allowable discharge limit or instantaneous limit means the maximum concentration of a pollutant allowed to be discharged at any time determined from the analysis of any discrete or composited sample collected independent of the industrial flow rate and the duration of the sampling event interceptor means any device designed and installed to separate and retain for removal by automatic or manual means deleterious hazardous or undesirable matter from wastewater while permitting the wastewater to discharge to the potw this definition includes grease interceptors and traps oil and water separators sand interceptors and traps and similar devices whether located inside or outside of a building interference means a discharge which alone or in conjunction with a discharge from another source interferes with the operation of the potw including sewage sludge use or disposal and which causes a violation of the citys npdes permit this definition includes any discharge causing the potw to be out of compliance with any applicable federal regulations or permits or any other stringent state or local regulations such regulations include of the act  the solid waste disposal act including title ii commonly referred to as the rcra  any state regulations contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to subtitle d of the solid waste disposal act  the toxic substances control act  and the marine protection research and sanctuaries act lateral means the connection from a gravity sewer line to a building drain local limit means the specific discharge limits developed and enforced by the city upon industrial or commercial facilities to implement the general and specific discharge prohibitions listed in 622 fac and 40 cfr 4035a1 and b medical waste means isolation wastes infectious agents human blood and blood products pathological wastes sharps body parts contaminated bedding surgical wastes potentially contaminated laboratory wastes and dialysis wastes meter means the measuring device owned and installed by the city on a service line for the purpose of accurately measuring water use by a customer metered water means the amount of water delivered to a city water customer as measured by a city water meter  or the amount of water delivered to a city sewer customer as measured by a city water meter whether or not the sewer customer is served by city water new source means 1 a source from which there is or may be a discharge where construction commenced after publication of proposed pretreatment standards under c of the act which would apply to the source if the standards were thereafter promulgated in accordance with c of the act provided that a the source is constructed at a site at which no other source is located  or b the source totally replaces the process or production equipment producing the discharge at an existing source  or c the production and wastewater generating processes of the source are substantially independent of an existing source at the same site in determining whether sources are substantially independent the city manager considers factors such as the extent to which the new source is integrated with the existing source and the extent to which the new source is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source 2 if construction on a site containing an existing source does not meet the criteria of subsections b and c above but otherwise alters replaces or adds to existing process or production equipment then such construction is a modification of the existing source and not a new source 3 construction of a new source is considered to have commenced if the owner or operator has a begun or caused to begin as part of a continuous onsite construction program 1 any placement assembly or installation of facilities or equipment  or 2 significant site preparation work clearing excavating demolition or equipment removal necessary for the placement assembly or installation of new source facilities or equipment  or b entered into a binding contract to purchase facilities or equipment intended to be used in its operation within a reasonable time options to purchase contracts which can be terminated or modified without substantial loss and contracts for feasibility engineering and design studies do not constitute a binding contract under this paragraph noncontact cooling water means water used for cooling which does not come into direct contact with any raw material intermediate product waste product or finished product nonsignificant categorical industrial user means an industrial user that discharges one hundred 100 gallons per day gpd or less of total categorical wastewater excluding sanitary noncontact cooling and boiler blowdown wastewater unless specifically included in the pretreatment standard and a has consistently complied with all applicable categorical pretreatment standards and requirements  b annually submits the certification statement required in subsection 6217 fac together with any additional information necessary to support the certification statement  and c never discharges any untreated categorical process wastewater normal working hours means monday 00 am pm except holidays north american industrial classification system naics a classification pursuant to the north american industrial classification system manual issued by the united states office of management and budget offsite facilities means water mains and pumps sewer lines force mains and lift stations constructed to connect onsite facilities to the nearest point in the existing water or sewer system at which adequate capacity is available to meet the requirements of the new services onsite facilities means the water mains services meters fire hydrants sewer lines force mains lift stations and pretreatment equipment installed within a development oversized facility means a facility designed to be larger than that required to serve a single development or the extension of a facility a greater length than that required to serve a single development ph means a measure of the acidity or alkalinity of a solution expressed in standard units passa discharge entering the potw at a concentration equal to or greater than the effluent concentration or which is incapable of being adequately treated by the potw or which exits the potw into waters of the united states in quantities or concentrations which alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources is a cause of a violation of any requirement of the citys npdes permit including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation person means any individual partnership copartnership firm company corporation association joint stock company trust estate governmental entity or any other legal entity or their legal representatives agents or assigns this definition includes all federal state and local government entities plumbing system means the water supply and distribution pipes fixtures traps vents building drains building sewers water treatment equipment and related appurtenances on the customer side of the point of service point of service means 1 in the case of a water service without a backflow preventer the point where the female pipe thread on the water meter is connected to the customers service line  2 in the case of a water service with a backflow preventer the point where the female pipe thread on the customer leg of the backflow preventer is connected to the customers service line  and 3 in the case of sewer service the point where the lateral crosses the customers property line pollutant means any dredged spoils solid waste incinerator residue sewage sludge munitions medical wastes chemical wastes biological materials radioactive materials heat wrecked or discarded equipment rock sand dirt municipal waste industrial waste agricultural waste and certain characteristics of wastewater eg ph temperature tss turbidity color cbod cod toxicity or odor pretreatment means the reduction of the amount of pollutants the elimination of pollutants or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater prior to or in lieu of introducing such pollutants into the potw this reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical chemical or biological processes  by process changes  or by other means except by diluting the concentration of the pollutants unless allowed by an applicable pretreatment standard pretreatment requirements means any substantive or procedural requirement related to pretreatment imposed on a user other than a pretreatment standard pretreatment standards or standards means prohibited discharge standards categorical pretreatment standards and local limits prohibited discharge standards means absolute prohibitions against the discharge of certain substances these prohibitions appear in section 2678 of this sewer means a sewer owned by the city specifically designed constructed and intended to convey wastewater to the potw typically by gravity from manhole to manhole or from manhole to pump station and to which stormwater and ground water are excluded publicly owned treatment works potw means a treatment works as defined by the act 33 usc  1292 owned by the city this definition includes any devices or systems used in the collection storage treatment recycling and reclamation of sewage or industrial wastes of a liquid nature and any conveyances which convey wastewater to a treatment plant this definition includes public sewers gravity sewers manholes pump stations force mains laterals and all other related appurtenances septic tank waste means any sewage from holding tanks septic tanks vessels chemical toilets campers and trailers separator see interceptor severe property damage means substantial physical damage to property damage to the treatment facilities causing them to become inoperable or substantial and permanent loss of natural resources reasonably expected to occur in the absence of a bypass severe property damage does not mean economic loss caused by delays in production sewage means human excrement and gray water from showers dishwashing operations etc significant industrial user siu means 1 a user subject to categorical pretreatment standards  or 2 a user that a discharges an average of twentyfive thousand 25000 gpd or more of process wastewater to the potw excluding sanitary noncontact cooling and boiler blowdown wastewater  b contributes a process waste stream which makes up five 5 percent or more of the average dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the potw treatment plant  or c is designated as such by the city on the basis that it has a reasonable potential for adversely affecting the potws operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement 3 the city manager may determine that an industrial user subject to categorical pretreatment standards under rule 62 fac including 40 cfr subchapter n parts 405 is a nonsignificant categorical industrial user 4 if the city manager finds that a user meeting the criteria in subsection 2 above has no reasonable potential for adversely affecting the potws operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement then the city manager may at any time on his own initiative or in response to a petition received from a user and in accordance with procedures in rule 622e fac determine that such user should not be considered a significant industrial user significant noncompliance means 1 chronic violations of wastewater discharge limits defined here as those in which sixtysix 66 percent or more of all of the measurements taken for the same pollutant parameter taken during a sixmonth period exceed by any magnitude a numeric pretreatment standard or requirement including instantaneous limits  2 technical review criteria trc violations defined here as those in which thirtythree 33 percent or more of wastewater measurements taken for each pollutant parameter during a sixmonth period equal or exceed the product of the numeric pretreatment standard or requirement including instantaneous limits multiplied by the applicable trc trc equals one and fourtenths 14 for cbod tss total oil and grease and equals one and twotenths 12 for all other pollutants except ph  or 3 any other violation of a pretreatment standard or requirement daily maximum longterm average instantaneous limit or narrative standard that the city manager believes has caused either alone or in combination with other discharges interference or passincluding endangering the health of potw personnel or the general public  or 4 any discharge of pollutants that has caused imminent endangerment to the public or to the environment or that has resulted in the city managers exercise of emergency authority to halt or prevent such a discharge  or 5 failing to meet within ninety 90 days after the schedule date a compliance schedule milestone contained in a wastewater discharge permit or enforcement order for starting construction completing construction or attaining final compliance  or 6 failing to provide within fortyfive 45 days after the due date required reports such as baseline monitoring reports ninetyday compliance reports periodic selfmonitoring reports and reports on compliance with compliance schedules  or 7 failing to accurately report noncompliance  or 8 any other violation or group of violations including violation of best management practices that the city manager determines may adversely affect the operation or implementation of the local pretreatment program slug load or slug discharge means any discharge at a flow rate or concentration which could cause a violation of the prohibited discharge standards in section 2678 of this slug discharge is any discharge of a nonroutine episodic nature including but not limited to an accidental spill or a noncustomary batch discharge which has a reasonable potential to cause interference or pass or in any other way violate the potws regulations local limits or permit conditions source means any building structure facility or installation from which there is or may be a discharge of pollutants standard methods means those procedures or methods established by the latest edition of the standard methods for the examination of water and sewage which is prepared approved and published jointly by the american public health association the american water works association and the water environment federation stormwater means any flow occurring during or following any form of natural precipitation and resulting from such precipitation including snowmelt stubout means a short section of water or sewer main intended for future use total suspended solids tss or suspended solids means the total suspended matter that floats on the surface of or is suspended in water wastewater or other liquid and which is removable by laboratory filtering upset means an exceptional incident in which there is unintentional and temporary noncompliance with categorical pretreatment standards because of factors beyond the reasonable control of the industrial user user means any person as defined herein discharging wastewater to the potw wastewater means liquid and watercarried industrial wastes and sewage from residential dwellings commercial buildings industrial and manufacturing facilities and institutions whether treated or untreated which contribute to the potw wastewater treatment plant means that portion of the potw designed to provide treatment of municipal sewage and industrial waste  31102   92503   52305   62308   102411   92815 service area established the city of st augustine service area hereafter referred to as service area is depicted on the service area map the service area map is on file with the city clerk for the city  31102 authorization to extend city utilities within the service area the city is authorized and empowered to extend its water and wastewater utilities wells mains manholes gravity sewers pump stations pumps and storage tanks to all areas within the service area  31102 requirement to connect to city water and wastewater when available a development inside the city limits all new development within the city limits is required to connect to city water and wastewater service when available all existing development within the city limits is required to connect to city water and wastewater service within three hundred sixtyfive 365 days of when such service becomes available b development outside the city limits all new development within the service area is required to connect to city water and wastewater service when available all existing development within the service area is required to connect to city water and wastewater service when available if and when the existing private water system wastewater system well or septic tank fails  31102 availability of water and wastewater service a water service for properties inside and outside the city limits water service for properties inside and outside the city limits shall be deemed available when a city water main exists in an easement or rightofway that abuts the property b wastewater service wastewater service for properties inside or outside the city limits shall be deemed available as follows 1 for a residential subdivision lot singlefamily dwelling unit or an establishment with a flow of one thousand 1000 gpd or less service is available when a gravity sewer line exists in a public easement or rightofway that abuts the property line of the lot dwelling unit or establishment 2 for an establishment with a flow exceeding one thousand 1000 gpd service is available when a gravity sewer main forcemain or lift station exists in a public easement or rightofway that abuts the property of the establishment or is within fifty 50 feet of the establishments property line as accessed via existing easements or rightsofway 3 for proposed residential subdivisions with more than fifty 50 lots for proposed commercial or industrial subdivisions with more than five 5 lots and for areas zoned or used for industrial or manufacturing service is available when a sewer system exists within onefourth 14 mile of the development as measured and accessed via existing easements or rightsofway 4 for repairs or modifications within areas zoned or used for an industrial or manufacturing use service is available when a sewer system exists within five hundred 500 feet of an establishments or dwelling units sewer stubout as measured and accessed via existing easements or rightsofway  31102 prohibiting utilities of similar character within the service area no private or public utility is authorized to construct within the service area any system work project or utility of similar character to that being operated by the city unless specifically approved to do so by the city manager  31102 enforcement a failure to connect or pay connection charges if any development within the service area fails to connect as provided for in this chapter the city has the right to file an action in circuit court to require connection upon showing that service is available as provided in this chapter if any development within the service area fails to pay connection charges the city has the right to seek the sums that are due in a court of law b failure to pay user fees if any customer in the service area fails to pay user fees the city has the right to seek the sums that are due in a court of law or to discontinue service until such sums including penalties established by this chapter are paid c other violations violations of any provision of this chapter except as specified in paragraphs a and b above or elsewhere in this chapter will be addressed as provided by section 18 of this chapter 2 of this as provided by law  31102 severability if any section sentence clause or phrase of this chapter is held to be invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction then said holding shall in no way affect the validity of the remaining portions of this chapter if any part of the service area established by this chapter is held to be invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction then said holding shall in no way affect the validity of the remaining parts of the service area  31102 secs 26112625  reserved article ii  policies and procedures emergency restrictions and service disruptions a emergencies in the event that emergency conditions such as prolonged drought freezing temperatures or other causes exist that adversely impact the city water system the city manager is authorized to shut off or restrict the use of water within the service area as necessary to protect the public health safety and welfare and the city water system b taps extensions and repairs the city manager has the right to shut off the water from any main upon notice while making taps extensions and repairs  31102 city liability the city is not liable for any damage resulting from water service disruptions caused by bursting or leaking of any water main  shutting off the water for taps extensions and repairs  or from the accidental failure of the water system for any cause whatsoever  31102 prohibited practices it is unlawful for any person to do any of the following 1 to alter or damage any city water meter  to prevent any city water meter from accurately registering the quantity of water passing meter  or to hinder or interfere with the proper action or registration of any such meter 2 to tamper with break alter uncover deface damage or destroy any part of the city water system or potw 3 to knowingly use water from any unauthorized connection to the city water system 4 to wastewater fixtures or plumbing or to allow water to run continually from any fixture inside or outside a building 5 to turn water on without making the deposit required to activate the account 6 to possess a hydrant wrench valve meter box meter cap or any component part of the city water system without specific authorization from the city manager 7 to connect any private water system to the city water system without prior authorization from the city manager and prior approval of the appropriate regulatory agencies 8 to occupy any building connected to the city water system or potw without first making the deposit required to activate the account 9 to place or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city service area any human or animal excrement garbage or other objectionable waste 10 to discharge to any waterbody in the city service area any sewage or other polluted waters except where suitable treatment has been provided as required by this chapter 11 to construct maintain or use any privy privy vault septic tank cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage inside the city service area except as herein provided 12 to make allow or use any cross connection 13 to connect roof downspouts exterior foundation drains or any other source of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to the potw 14 to connect any appurtenance in any manner to use water without the consent of the city or without the water use being recorded by a city water meter 15 to tap or make any connection to any part of the city water system or potw without specific written authorization from the city manager 16 to connect a private fire hydrant to the city water system 17 to construct any utility system intended to be transferred to the city upon completion without construction plans designed by an engineer registered in the state of florida and approved in advance in writing by the city manager  31102 applications for service a applications required all persons desiring firsttime connection to the city water system or potw or desiring separation of water or sewer service must submit an application for utility service to the city manager additionally all persons desiring changes to an existing water or sewer connection such as due to changing the use of an existing building must submit an application for utility service to the city manager such application must be on a form prescribed by the city manager and must contain all the information required for review b application fees review and permitting fees for applications for new service applications for change in service applications for line extensions or applications for utility service involving development orders may be adopted by resolution of the city commission fees shall apply to all applications for customers inside and outside the city limits c application requirements applications for new service applications for change in service applications for line extensions or applications for utility service involving development orders shall be in accordance with the city of st augustine standards and specifications design manual and details as amended and with review and permitting procedures and policies adopted by the city manager these requirements shall apply to all applications for providing utility service inside and outside the city limits  92211 extensions water and sewer main extensions must be paid for designed and constructed as follows 1 individual customers for extensions to serve an individual customer where the extension will enable the city to provide service to other future customers the customer must pay the flow proportional transmission and distribution t&d fee established in this chapter for extensions to serve an individual customer where the extension will not enable the city to provide service to other future customers the customer must pay the cost of the extension the city reserves the right not to construct an extension when it is economically unfeasible to do so 2 extensions within a subdivision or development the entire cost of the water and sewer system within the limits of a subdivision or development must be paid by the developer except as specifically authorized by the city manager 3 extensions to connect the existing city water or sewer system to a subdivision or development the cost of any extension between that part of the existing water or sewer system with sufficient capacity to provide service to the subdivision or development and the point of connection to the subdivision or development may be shared between the city and the developer cost sharing arrangements are made on a casebycase basis at the discretion of the city manager 4 oversized mains the city reserves the right to require oversized water and sewer mains to serve any development the city may pay the costs to oversize the mains based on the difference between city estimates of the cost of the oversized mains and the cost of the mains normally required to serve the development 5 design extensions must be designed by a professional engineer registered in the state of florida in the event that the customers engineer designs the extension the city manager will review and approve the plans for the extension prior to permitting 6 construction extensions must be constructed by the city or by a licensed underground utility contractor construction must be in accordance with the approved plans the city manager has the right to inspect extensions during construction to ensure that construction is in accordance with the approved plans 7 ownership of extension following construction and acceptance by the city title to the entire extension up to and including the meter backflow preventer or sewer lateral will be vested in the city 8 rights of additional extension the city manager has the right to add new or additional customers and additional extensions to any city water or sewer main at any time without the permission of any customer contributing to the original extension 9 easement required prior to constructing any extension in a development and not located in a public rightofway the developer must provide a copy of a recorded easement granting the city access to tap maintain repair or extend water or sewer lines within or development 10 payment of flow proportional connection charges the customer must pay flow proportional connection charges in addition to any main extension costs the flow proportional connection charges must be paid before service is provided 11 utility service agreement required the city manager reserves the right to require that the developer and the city enter into a written utility service agreement specifying the above terms prior to the construction of any extension  31102   92503 system specifications the city manager has the right to specify the size type routing location and design of all mains valves taps meters backflow preventers manholes gravity sewers pump stations and any other components being added to the city water system or potw additionally all components used in the construction extension and maintenance of the city water system or potw must be designed and constructed to meet or exceed city standards and specifications  31102 water connections meters and submetering a separately owned properties separately owned properties will not be supplied with water common meter b water service lines water service lines supplying more than one 1 building from a single water meter are prohibited except when specifically approved by the city manager c reselling city water or sewer service submetering and reselling city water or sewer service by private submetering on the customer side of the city water meter is allowed subject to the following conditions 1 private meters used for this purpose must be installed maintained and read at the expense of the customer 2 unless specifically approved by the city manager customers cannot charge or collect from unit owners tenants or other persons more than the fees and charges billed by the city plus actual administrative costs 3 water and sewer sold to st johns county are subject to conditions of a separate interlocal agreement  31102 sewer connections and building sewers a sewer connection required each building must be provided with a separate building sewer with a separate connection to the main however in the case where one 1 building stands at the rear of another on a single lot and public sewer is not available and cannot be extended to the rear building then both buildings may share a common connection at the main in this case if a separate water meter serves each building then sewer service will be billed to each building b meter required no person shall discharge wastewater to the potw unless there is a water meter permitted or installed by the city accessible to the city meter reader and located to meter all water entering the premises c costs of building sewers the developer must pay all costs related to construction and installation of the building sewer the developer must indemnify the city from any loss or damage caused directly or indirectly by installation of the building sewer d design and construction of building sewers the size slope alignment materials and construction methods related to the installation and connection of the building sewer must all conform to the requirements of the city building code a cleanout must be installed at the property line all excavations for building sewer installations must be adequately guarded with barricades and lights to protect the public from hazard public property disturbed in the course of the construction must be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city manager e location of building sewers whenever possible the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor in any building in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer wastewater carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer f connection of building sewers to public sewer connection of the building sewer to the public sewer must conform to the requirements of the city building code g maintenance and repair of sewer mains manholes laterals and building sewers in areas where the city provides gravity sewer service the city provides normal maintenance to the manholes and sewer mains to maintain free flow 1 for properties connected to the city gravity sewer system the property owner is responsible for maintaining free flow from the building building sewer and sewer lateral to the city sewer main this includes the connection of the building sewer to the sewer lateral and the removal of obstructions grease buildups clogs root intrusions or any other types of stoppages in the lateral or building sewer 2 the property owner shall have a standard cleanout at or near the property line the cleanout shall be a minimum of four 4 inches in diameter and facing the city sewer main the cleanout must be at or above ground level and be equipped with a removable threaded cap the property owner is responsible for knowing the location of this cleanout and for maintaining the cleanout and cap in working order if no cleanout exists the property owner must install one prior to the city investigating reports of stoppages in the lateral or building sewer line 3 in the event of a blockage in the lateral or building sewer line the property owner must obtain the services of a licensed plumber to investigate the problem 4 in the event that the blockage cannot be removed by the licensed plumber the licensed plumber shall contact the city to request a site investigation during normal working hours 5 if the sewer lateral blockage is caused by structural damage to the sewer lateral owned by the city as determined by a licensed plumber and field verified by the city at the sewer cleanout it is the responsibility of the city to repair or replace the lateral without charge to the property owner 6 if the sewer blockage is not caused by structural damage to the sewer lateral owned by the city as determined by a licensed plumber and field verified by the city at the sewer cleanout but is instead the responsibility of the owner lodging the complaint the city may hold the owner or licensed plumber responsible for all labor and equipment costs associated with the sewer complaint investigation 7 all city sewer main blockages including manhole problems are the responsibility of the city all repairs to sewer laterals located in the public rightofway are the responsibility of the city  31102   91709 fire system water service and fire hydrants a fire system water services no connections of any kind are allowed to a fire protection service other than those necessary for fire protection all water used for purposes other than fire protection must be taken from a separate metered tap connected directly to the city main no person is allowed to use a fire system connection for any purpose other than actually extinguishing a fire b backflow preventers all fire system water services must be equipped with a backflow preventer c enforcement in the event that any fire system water service customer fails to comply with the requirements of this such service the city manager may cut off the water supply the water supply will remain cut off until the customer has complied with the requirements of this fire system water service d public fire hydrants a public fire hydrant is a fire hydrant meeting all of the following criteria 1 the hydrant is in the city utility service area and supplied by water via the city water system 2 the hydrant is installed in a public rightofway or in a recorded utility easement granting the city access for repairs and maintenance  3 the hydrant has been either installed by the city or accepted by the city billofsale public hydrants are the maintenance responsibility of the city e private fire hydrants a private fire hydrant is a fire hydrant meeting all of the following criteria 1 the hydrant is in the city utility service area and supplied by water via the city water system 2 the hydrant is not installed in a public rightofway or in a recorded utility easement granting the city access for repairs and maintenance  3 the hydrant has not been installed by the city or accepted by the city billofsale private hydrants are not the maintenance responsibility of the city the city water customer on whose property a private fire hydrant is located shall be billed monthly for availability of water at a rate established by the city  31102   92205 backflow prevention a facilities requiring backflow preventers no consumer of water from the city water system shall have a cross connection or potential cross connection either inside or outside of any building or buildings without a backflow prevention device being installed to prevent any and all backflow into the public water system cross connection is defined in fac b installation and maintenance connections to the public water service that require backflow prevention are the responsibility of the customer and shall be installed tested and maintained by the customer in conformance with fac and american water works association manual m14 and the city of st augustine cross connection control manual c city reserves right to disconnect water the city manager has the right to disconnect the water service to any customer where inadequate backflow prevention exists at the service connection water service will not be restored until such conditions or defects are corrected and until all penalties and service charges resulting from the disconnection and subsequent reconnection have been paid inadequate backflow prevention exists when 1 a backflow preventer is required but has not been installed  or 2 a required backflow preventer has been removed tampered with altered or bypassed  or 3 any unprotected cross connection exists on the customers premises  or 4 any other cross connection exists which may jeopardize public health d administer and enforce the city shall have the right to inspect customer facilities to ensure protection of the city water system prevention administer and enforce compliance to the cross connection control program and reporting requirements to regulatory authorities and may exact fees for the administration of this program  31102   91709 secs 26362650  reserved article iii  connection charges and rates connection charges a in general connection charges including backflow preventer fees and surcharges may be established and adjusted from time to time by resolution of the city commission passed after public hearing charges must be paid prior to service being provided except as specifically addressed in subsection e below connection charges run with the property customer is responsible for costs associated with making connection to the city utility including but not limited to materials labor permits restoration inspections of the actual connection and line extension as well as flow based fees related to treatment facility transmission and distribution and collection system capital improvements b backflow preventer fees all utility customers who are required to maintain a backflow preventer will be assessed a surcharge for the purpose of administration compliance and enforcement of the cross connection control regulations c water and sanitary sewer surcharge areas and fees 1 the northwest area forcemain surcharge intended to cover capital improvements associated with the northwest area forcemain extension shall be calculated on a gallons per day gpd of flow basis the surcharge fees may be adjusted from time to time by resolution of the city commission 2 upon the request and recommendation of the city manager the city commission may create additional water andor sanitary sewer surcharge areas and associated surcharge fees by adoption of a resolution after public hearing at a duly noticed public meeting the surcharge fees once adopted may be adjusted from time to time by resolution of the city commission at a duly noticed public meeting d consumer price index adjustment all connection charges for water and sewer service provided by this article may be adjusted annually by the city manager with the percentage change in the consumer price index as published by the us department of labor cpiu class d south region class d  no less than 50000 population from may 1 of the preceding calendar year until april 30 of the present calendar year such adjusted rates shall supersede the rates set forth in this article 1 the adjusted connection charges will be applied to all letters of availability dated on or after october 1 of each year or on or after the effective date of the adopting resolution 2 the percentage change in the consumer price index will be applied to the flow proportional connection charges as follows a multiply the percentage change in the consumer price index from may 1 of the preceding calendar year of the present calendar year times the existing flow proportional connection charges b add the product to the existing flow proportional connection charges and round to the nearest cent e refund of connection charges connection charges as defined herein paid prior to the installation of facilities to provide service to a property run with the real property benefitted by the services and facilities provided and will be refunded only to the owner of the property at the time of the refund request subject to all of the following conditions 1 the facilities have not been installed  2 no flow capacity has been reserved with the florida department of environmental protection fdep or any such agency exercising jurisdiction over the property benefitted by the services and facilities and none of the flow capacity has been placed in service for the subject property  3 costs incurred by the city related to such facilities are deducted prior to making the refund  4 the city shall not pay interest on the connection charges refunded  5 the refund is requested within five 5 years of the date of the original connection charges payment this subsection 5 shall apply only to connection charges paid on or after   6 the burden of proof for having paid connection charges rests with the person or entity seeking refund of the connection charges  7 the person or entity requesting the refund of the connection charges requests the refund in writing  and 8 the request for refund of connection charges is approved by the city manager 9 if the property is under foreclosure proceedings or if the city is otherwise placed on notice of pending litigation relating to rights that run with the land no final determination of a refund shall be executed pending the outcome of the litigation f lease of increments to base flow rate fee to commercial users providing at least one hundred 100 full time equivalent jobs at the property benefited by the water and sewer service 1 authority to lease the city manager is hereby authorized to lease for a designated term of time as determined by the city manager any increment to the minimum flow based fees created by section 2651e of this as amended from time to time such leases shall be made available only to commercial users of water and sewer utility services who create and maintain at least one hundred 100 full time equivalent jobs at the property benefited by the water and sewer service 2 calculation of amounts due the city manager shall employ the following methodology to calculate the amounts due a the city shall collect all connection charges described in sections 2651b c d e f g h and i of this as applicable and as amended from time to time b the city shall collect the lowest flow based fee for nonresidential uses as established by section 2651e of this as amended from time to time c the city may lease any increment between the flow based fee for retail sales as provided in section 2653a17a of this as amended from time to time and the flow based fee for the nonresidential use of the real property benefiting from the water and sewer service as provided in section 2653a of this as amended from time to time d the amount due for the incremental flow based fee lease shall be an amount of not less than two and onehalf 212 percent of the incremental amount for each year of the lease term 3 payment due dates the first annual lease payment shall be due in advance and simultaneously with the payment of all other fees required by this section 2651 subsequent annual lease payments shall be due on the anniversary date of the first such payment 4 failure of payment in the event any annual lease payment becomes delinquent for a period of thirty 30 days after the scheduled payment due date the city may discontinue water and sewer service to the benefited property and seek relief
